review.title: Efficient Informative Sensing using Multiple Robots
review.abstract: The need for efficient monitoring of spatio-temporal dynamics in large environmental applications, such as the water quality monitoring in rivers and lakes, motivates the use of robotic sensors in order to achieve sufficient spatial coverage. Typically, these robots have bounded resources, such as limited battery or limited amounts of time to obtain measurements. Thus, careful coordination of their paths is required in order to maximize the amount of information collected, while respecting the resource constraints. In this paper, we present an efficient approach for near-optimally solving the NP-hard optimization problem of planning such informative paths. In particular, we first develop eSIP (efficient Single-robot Informative Path planning), an approximation algorithm for optimizing the path of a single robot. Hereby, we use a Gaussian Process to model the underlying phenomenon, and use the mutual information between the visited locations and remainder of the space to quantify the amount of information collected. We prove that the mutual information collected using paths obtained by using eSIP is close to the information obtained by an optimal solution. We then provide a general technique, sequential allocation, which can be used to extend any single robot planning algorithm, such as eSIP, for the multi-robot problem. This procedure approximately generalizes any guarantees for the single-robot problem to the multi-robot case. We extensively evaluate the effectiveness of our approach on several experiments performed in-field for two important environmental sensing applications, lake and river monitoring, and simulation experiments performed using several real world sensor network data sets.

sections.text: Typically, these robots have limited resources, such as limited battery capacity or limited time to perform measurements, so careful coordination of their paths is required to maximize the amount of information collected while respecting resource constraints. In this paper, we present an efficient approach to approaching the NP hardware optimization problem in planning such informative paths. In particular, we first develop eSIP (Efficient Single Robot Information Path Planning), an approximation algorithm for optimizing the paths of a single robot. To do this, we use a Gaussian process to model the underlying phenomenon, and use the mutual information between the locations visited and the remnants of space to quantify the amount of information collected. We demonstrate that the mutual information collected through the use of eSIP is close to the information achieved by optimally solving multiple problems.

sections.heading: 2.3 Online vs Offline Path Planning:
sections.text: Many applications of robotic route planning, such as search and rescue operations, involve uncertain environments with complex dynamics that can only be partially observed. Informative route planning - selecting the best places that can be observed under certain perceptual constraints in such uncertain environments requires a trade-off between exploration (collecting information about the environment) and exploitation (making the most effective use of current beliefs about the state of the environment). We distinguish between two different classes of algorithms: non-adaptive (offline) algorithms that plan and define paths before making observations, and adaptive (online) algorithms that update and reschedule when new information is collected. Both the online and offline settings are NP-hard optimization problems. In this paper, we discuss only the approach algorithms for offline setting that incorporate the known belief about the environment for efficient route planning, and we will expand our approach to exploration and modeling.

sections.text: The basic strategy of the algorithm is a "divide-and-conquer" approach. Each path from the starting position (s) to the end position (t) has a middle position (vm), so that there are the same number of locations (or different locations) on both sides of the path. Thus, the problem of finding a path can be divided into two smaller sub-problems to find smaller sub-paths (s − vm and vm − t) and then link these small sub-paths with each other. sections.heading: 5.1 Structure of the Search Problem
sections.text: It is instructive to look at the recursive structure generated by the recursive-greedy algorithm. Fig. 4 illustrates an example of such a structure when recursive-greedy for our sea sensor application with the given start (s) and end (t) location and an upper limit on the path cost (B). Searching with recursive-greedy can be graphically represented as a sum-greedy tree. At the root is a maximum node representing the goal of finding an s − t path with the highest possible reward, while the cost of the path is limited by the budget B. For each such maximum node, the children in the search tree represent sum nodes corresponding to the sum of the rewards collected on both sides of the middle location. Therefore, at the end of the first iteration, the graphical representation will represent a maximum node as root with multiple sum nodes as children, for each feasible middle location and any budget.

sections.text: This heuristic, known as sub-approximation (Ibaraki et al., 1983), is effective in practice. sections.heading: 8. Experimental Results
sections.text: We conducted several experiments both in the field and in the simulation (using real sensor data sets) to demonstrate the usefulness of our proposed algorithm for various different environmental sensor applications. In-field experiments were conducted using the Networked Infomechanical System (NIMS) (Jordan et al., 2007), a tied robotic system. Real sensor data sets used to conduct scaling and multi-robot experiments in the simulation were collected using either a network of static sensors or a robotic boat.

sections.heading: 8.1 In-field Experiments
sections.text: Several on-site experiments were conducted to demonstrate the applicability of modelling a phenomenon as a Gaussian process and the use of eMIP for path planning for various aquatic sensor applications, including a river monitoring application with the aim of investigating salt concentration, and lake monitoring for several applications of interest to limonologists. In each of these applications, NIMS was used to monitor a cross-section (two-dimensional vertical plane in an environment) in the aquatic environment. The interesting phenomenon is then modeled as a Gaussian process and we use the mutual information criterion as a submodular reward function to quantify the informatics of observation sites. To quantify the efficiency of our approach, the learned Gaussian process model and the mutual information target are then modeled as input to eMIP and the subset of sites as output by the algorithm, with NIMS again being used as a robotic platform to calculate the phenomenon in unobserved places (before predicting the Root and Root) of the phenomenon in front of all.

sections.heading: 8.2 Experiments on Sensing Datasets
sections.text: Several experiments were performed in the simulation using real-world data sets to analyze the scaling of our algorithm for different approaches, such as variation in experimental costs, exponential increase in budget allocation, change in the size of spaceship cells, and comparison of several heuristics. Three different real-world data sets were used for these experiments, the first consisting of measurements of temperature in Lake Fulmor, James Reserve (hereinafter referred to as the "Lake Temperature Data Set").

sections.heading: 8.2.1 COMPARISON WITH RECURSIVE-GREEDY ALGORITHM:
sections.text: In order to compare the performance of our approach with the recursive-greedy algorithm, as suggested by Chekuri et al., we chose a subset of 23 locations from the 52 locations of the Berkeley temperature dataset. Since the runtime of the recursive-greedy dataset is quasi-polynomial and was very large for the entire dataset, a small subset of locations was selected. Fig. 11a and Fig. 11b show the comparison in computational effort and the rewards collected for this smaller dataset for the two algorithms. As can be seen from the diagrams, our approach offers a significant improvement in runtime (by several orders of magnitude at higher budget values) at (almost) the same reward collected. Since the recursive-greedy algorithm is essentially a search method with greedily limited search space, this result also indicates that an exhaustive search across all paths leads to even a small recursive leap in value by 100 steps (the additional increment in the budget).

sections.heading: 8.2.2 COMPARISON WITH UNIFORM SAMPLE SPACING:
sections.text: We compared the performance of eMIP to a simple uniform sample distance algorithm known as uniform density. In the case of uniform density, we greedily select two observatories within each of the closest cells and calculate the corresponding path costs and path rewards. The uniform density algorithm provides the best possible path out of all possible simple uniform sample distance algorithms based on greedy observation selections within each cell. Fig. 12b compares the uniform density reward sent to eMIP for the lake temperature dataset. Increased collected reward by eMIP compared to uniform density empirically justifies the complexity of eMIP. In addition, eMIP provides a strong approximation guarantee that is not possible for a uniform sample distance algorithm. Fig. 13 illustrates a path for the lake temperature dataset selected by eMIP compared to uniform density and shows that samples were not selected for a uniform observation location while not selected for a number of observatories.

sections.heading: 8.2.4 VARIATION IN SENSING COST:
sections.text: Fig. 14a and Fig. 14b compare the computational effort and the reward collected, as the acquisition costs for the precipitation dataset vary. As the experimental costs were reduced, more locations were observed for the same total input budget, resulting in an increased reward. This experiment shows that eMIP can be used over a wide range of acquisition costs, depending on the requirements of different environmental applications.

sections.heading: 8.2.6 ANALYSIS OF SPATIAL DECOMPOSITION:
sections.text: As discussed in Section 6, converting an SD-MIPP solution (a cell path) into a solution for MIPP (a path across observation sites) results in an additional path length that exceeds the input budget. This additional path length depends on the size of the cell (or the size of the grid that covers the entire spatial area) in the SD-MIPP problem and results in a compromise with the computational effort. Variations in the grid size result in corresponding variations in travel costs between adjacent cells, resulting in the possibility of traveling more cells for a denser grid with the same input budget constraints. However, in order to keep the experimental costs constant over the different grid size (since the experiment costs depend only on observed phenomena and are independent of the spatial decomposition), it has been scaled accordingly, in proportion to the travel costs between adjacent cells. However, Fig. 15a and Fig. 15b show the collected reward and the root center square (RMS) error if the number of robots was varied from one to three. Due to the sequential assignment error at the unobserved locations (removing the already selected locations before selecting the locations for the next robot) and the "information never hurts" principle, the collected reward increases if the number of robots was increased, thus reducing the corresponding root center square error for predicting at the unobserved locations. However, the incremental change in performance of one to two robots was greater than the incremental change of two to three robots, which is expected due to the submodularity (decrease in returns) property of the mutual information. sections.heading: 9. Related Work
sections.text: There is a wide variety of related work both in the theory of route planning and in its application areas. Approximation algorithms have been proposed for various related problems. In robotics, various path planning approaches for applications such as Simultaneous Localization and Mapping (SLAM) and Search and Exploration have been studied. In sensor networks and geostatistics, a closely related work examines the optimal placement of static sensors that model the phenomenon as Gaussian processes. Multiple adaptive sampling approaches have been studied to determine the subset of locations to be observed in order to effectively understand the phenomenon dynamics. Furthermore, similar approaches for planning paths for mobile robots that act as data mules and collect data scanned through the network of static sensors are being investigated.

sections.heading: 9.1 Operations Research
sections.text: An interesting special case of the MIPP problem is the case where each node has a fixed reward and the goal is to find a way to maximize the sum of these rewards (Traveling Salesman Problem with Profits, TSPP, Feillet et al., 2005).Such a sum of rewards is a modular (additive) function that is a specific case of submodular functions.A subcategory of the TSPP is an optimization problem defined in literature to maximize the rewards collected while keeping the associated costs lower than a specific budget B. This has been investigated in literature as an orientation problem (OP) or selective TSP (Laporte & Martello, 1990) or maximum capture problem (Kataoka & Morito, 1988).

sections.heading: 9.2 Robotic Applications
sections.text: There is considerable work in the robotics community to plan routes for multiple applications, including Simultaneous Localization and Mapping (SLAM) and Search and Exploration. For each of these applications, various approaches have been explored, including auction-based algorithms, data adaptive approaches, and information gathering algorithms.

sections.heading: 9.2.1 SIMULTANEOUS LOCALIZATION AND MAPPING:
sections.text: The aim of Simultaneous Localization And Mapping (SLAM) is to create maps of an environment by conducting an exploration of the environment with the aim of estimating the position of the robot and the characteristics of the world at the same time. Several approaches to optimize different objective functions have been proposed to perform route planning for SLAM. Bourgault et al. (2002) proposed an exploration framework using an occupancy grid (OG) to maximize the spatial decomposition of the observed environment, with the aim of maximizing mutual information about the OG map. Stachniss et al. (2005) developed a greedy algorithm for the selection of the next location to be visited in order to maximize the gains of information about the map.In contrast to such approaches, Sim and Roy (2005) attempted to optimize the entire trajectory, not only the next step, but their algorithm introduces some approaches without theoretical limitations to SLAM that are not quantifiable to SLAM (2000), which result in multiple explorations.

sections.heading: 9.2.2 SEARCH AND EXPLORATION:
sections.text: The search and reconnaissance application includes the path planning for a robot with the goal of finding a moving target (s) in a given environment, e.g. target monitoring in security applications and patient tracking in healthcare. Performing path planning using stochastic inference offers advantages of the robustness of capture and motion uncertainty, but with an additional complexity of computerized intractability. Roy and Earnest (2006) proposed an approach for effectively calculating the paths for target tracking based on maximizing mutual information (evaluated using the Changein variance of probability distribution), using a particle filtering approach, clustering over the particles, followed by path planning over these clusters. Lau et al. (2006) formulated indoor target tracking as generalizing anNP-complete optimal search path (OSP) problem (Trummel & Weisinger, 1986) while trying to optimize the probability of a target within a given time frame.

sections.heading: 9.2.3 PLANNING SYSTEMS AND APPLICATIONS:
sections.text: Certain applications in robotic route planning used plan diagrams (Blum & Furst, 1997) to calculate an estimate of the resources and time of states encountered during the search process to achieve the objectives. In the case of the problem of oversubscription planning - where only a subset of objectives can be achieved within the limited time or resources available to the planning system - Smith (2004) used orientation euristics to provide a set of objectives to be considered by the planner. Briel et al. (2004) proposed several heuristics to efficiently solve the problem of oversubscription planning. However, in each of the previously proposed heuristics the considered reward function is modular (additive). eMIP can be used to efficiently solve the problem of oversubscription planning in a submodular environment with strong approximation guarantees.

sections.heading: 9.3 Sensor Networks
sections.text: The modeling of phenomena to determine the optimal placement of a range of static sensors has been well researched in sensor networks and geostatistical communities, and Gaussian process models for spatial phenomena have been extensively studied (Cressie, 1991). Guestrin et al. (2005) demonstrated that the selection of sensor placement based on mutual information is nearly optimal in the case of phenomena regulated by Gaussian process models. Krause et al. (2006) expanded this work to include the communication costs between sensors while optimizing sensor placement. In a communication-constrained environment, similar to the problem of path planning considered in this paper, the greedy algorithm works poorly and more involved algorithms need to be developed. Batalin et al. (2004) showed that the combination of static and mobile sensors can significantly improve sensor performance even in a simple scenario.

sections.heading: 9.3.1 DATA COLLECTION FROM A SENSOR NETWORK:
sections.text: Another scenario in which a mobile robot can be combined with a network of static sensors is to improve the life span of the sensor network by carrying out the tours to collect the data collected by the static network. Somasundara et al. (2007) showed that the problem of collecting data when the environment has both spatial and temporal dynamics is NP-complete and provides an integral linear programming formulation for the same thing. They compared the performance of multiple heuristics in the simulation for both single and multi-robot scenarios. Meliou et al. (2007) proposed a non-short-sighted approach to the application of data acquisition tours, using an algorithm for submodular orientation runs (SOP) as a black box. They offered strong approximation guarantees and comprehensive empirical assessments showing the applicability of their approach to such applications. In this setting, eMIP can be used as an orientation algorithm to provide a better running time guarantee in addition to improved orientation algorithms.

sections.heading: 9.3.2 ADAPTIVE SAMPLING FOR ENVIRONMENTAL APPLICATIONS:
sections.text: Recent advances in robotics have opened up possibilities for highly accurate monitoring of dynamic environmental sensors. Rahimi et al. (2004) examined several strategies for adaptive environmental sampling. Singh et al. (2006) proposed a multi-scale adaptive sampling approach, in which the environment is sampled uniformly in the first phase, followed by sampling in places to minimize the mean square error most. They also expanded their approach for multiple robots without setting theoretical limits. Using several field trials and simulations with real sampling data, we show here that several such environmental phenomena can be sampled effectively with the help of eMIP.

sections.heading: 10. Conclusions and Future Work
sections.text: In this thesis, we introduced eSIP, an approximation algorithm for the efficient planning of informative paths. Our eSIP algorithm builds on the recursive-greedy algorithm of Chekuri and Pal (2005). eSIP preserves the approximation guarantees recursively-greedily, while overcoming its computational intractability through spatial decomposition and several bifurcated and bound approaches. We also presented a general approach, the sequential mapping, which extends each individual robot algorithm, such as eSIP, to the hiring of multiple robots, while providing a demonstrably strong approximation warranty.We also provide extensive empirical evaluations to demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach for real-world applications. We conducted several field experiments to perform two important environmental sensor conservation applications - maritime surveillance (on a small lake on the UIMC campus).We also research the reactive application of our system in order to demonstrate the effectiveness of this world.

A robotic boat, part of Networked Aquatic Microbial Observing System (NAMOS) (Dhariwal et al., 2006), was used to collect the surface temperature data around the lake, of width around 50 meters and length around 250 meters. As discussed earlier, understanding temperature distribution is of prime importance in limnology since it governs several physical phenomena occurring in the lake environment, including the growth of algal bloom. The average speed of the boat was approximately 0.4m/s. Half of the total measurements (218 different sensing locations) were used to learn a nonstationary Gaussian Process model by maximizing the marginal likelihood (Rasmussen & Williams, 2006), and the remaining measurements were used for experimentation. We divided the lake into 22 cells (except during the experiments for studying the effect of changing the size of the cell in spatial decomposition), with distance between adjacent cell approximately 21 meters. Based on the average speed, and motivated by a typical measurement duration of roughly 25 seconds, we set the experiment cost to be 10.5 meters (except during the experiment for understanding the effect of scaling the experimental cost). As our second dataset, we used data from an existing deployment of 52 wireless sensor motes to learn the amount of temperature variability at the Intel Research Laboratory, Berkeley (hereafter referred to as Berkeley temperature dataset). These sensing locations lie within a bounding region of length 45 meters and width 40 meters. We divided the complete region into a uniform grid containing 20 equal sized cells, and determined the experimental cost to be 9 meters (approximate distance to travel between adjacent cells). We learned a GP model as discussed by Krause et al. (2006). Finally, we explored the performance of our algorithm on a precipitation dataset collected from 167 regions of equal area, approximately 50 km apart, during the years 1949-1994.

metadata.abstractText: The need for efficient monitoring of spatio-temporal dynamics in large environmental applications, such as the water quality monitoring in rivers and lakes, motivates the use of robotic sensors in order to achieve sufficient spatial coverage. Typically, these robots have bounded resources, such as limited battery or limited amounts of time to obtain measurements. Thus, careful coordination of their paths is required in order to maximize the amount of information collected, while respecting the resource constraints. In this paper, we present an efficient approach for near-optimally solving the NP-hard optimization problem of planning such informative paths. In particular, we first develop eSIP (efficient Single-robot Informative Path planning), an approximation algorithm for optimizing the path of a single robot. Hereby, we use a Gaussian Process to model the underlying phenomenon, and use the mutual information between the visited locations and remainder of the space to quantify the amount of information collected. We prove that the mutual information collected using paths obtained by using eSIP is close to the information obtained by an optimal solution. We then provide a general technique, sequential allocation, which can be used to extend any single robot planning algorithm, such as eSIP, for the multi-robot problem. This procedure approximately generalizes any guarantees for the single-robot problem to the multi-robot case. We extensively evaluate the effectiveness of our approach on several experiments performed in-field for two important environmental sensing applications, lake and river monitoring, and simulation experiments performed using several real world sensor network data sets.
